descriptiveNote.p: [Iain mac Phadruig]; Crofter, Stilligarry, South Uist

biogHist.p: John MacInnes, Iain mac Phàdraig, was the son of Peter MacInnes, crofter, and Marion née MacLeod. Born c. 1805, by 1841 MacInnes was living in Staoidhligearraidh, South Uist, married to Marion (c. 1803– ). They had at least four children: Ann (b. 1835), Donald (b. 1836), Catherine or Kitty (b. 1839), and John (b. 1843). In 1871 the two youngest children were still living in the household, as well as an eighteen-year old farm servant Euphemia MacEachen, and two young grandchildren, Angus and Donald Campbell.

Alexander Carmichael visited John MacInnes ‘in his own house’ at Staoidhlegearraidh on 29 January 1875. Earlier on that day he had recorded a waulking song ’S e siud an leannan ainmeil from his daughter Ann, now married to Angus Campbell [CW MS 106 fos.4v-3v]. She evidently suggested to Carmichael that he visit her father, in whose household two of her children were then being brought up. An intensive and lengthy recording session ensued.

MacInnes began with a narrative about MacMhuirich Mór (‘the first who came to Staolig[earry] of the race’) and a fairy changeling [CW106/121], following on with a supernatural tale [CW106/122]; the local legend of MacMhuirich and the Mhuileartaich [CW106/123]; information concerning Dùn Raghnaill and Raghnall mac Ailein of Clan Ranald [CW106/124]; another supernatural tale, concerning seals [CW106/125]; the superhumanly aged Cailleach Ghlinn Dorcha [CW106/126]; and the extended Fenian tale Ceudach nan Collachain Òir [CW106/127]. This last he had heard from Donald MacPhee, Domhnall mac Aonghais ’ic Phroinsiais at Càrnan, Ìochdar, who had died some five or six years previously. The evidently inexhaustible MacInnes went on to narrate the story of MacMhuirich’s prayer [CW106/128], as well as giving a brief overview of the mythical origin of the family in Ireland, their discovery of the Red Book, and the land they possessed in South Uist CW106/128]. Finally, Carmichael recorded a fascinating extended list of titles of stories, ballads, and songs: what appears to be an inventory of John MacInnes’ complete repertoire [CW106/129].

Carmichael visited John MacInnes again on 30 March 1877, when he recorded a couple of protective charms for cattle: Rann Àirigh and Rann Spréidh, as well as Laoidh na h-Ighne, ‘Fhuair mo leannan am chadal’ [CW108/37, CW108/38, CW108/39, CW108/82, CW108/83]. This last had already been recorded from Duncan MacDonald, Donnchadh an Tàilleir, Snaoiseabhal, on 28 March 1871 [CW119/19].

According to the 1881 census, the now widowed John was being supported by his now married son John and his wife Catherine, who had just had a baby Marion, as well as his unmarried daughter Catherine. Another two grandchildren, Marion and Donald J Campbell, also shared what must have been a rather cramped household. In 1891 almost the same people lived there, although Marion Campbell had left, while Marion MacInnes now had a younger sister, six year old Mary.

On 16 September 1890 John MacInnes was visited again at his home in Staoidhlegearraidh, this time apparently by John Ewen MacRury [1853–1909] who was collecting material on behalf of Carmichael. Given that Carmichael was then planning a collection of charms and blessings which would eventually blossom into the first two volumes of Carmina Gadelica, it is interesting that three of the items MacRury recorded were identical to those written down by Carmichael from MacInnes in 1877: Laoidh na h-Ighne, Beannachadh Spréidhe (i.e. Rann Àirigh), and a brief allusion to the Òrtha na Buachailleachd which Carmichael had recorded that same year from Mary Stewart, Malacleit, Màiri Bhreac [CW108/10]. Also taken down were a version of the Altachadh Leapa, a story about the haunted Gleann Liadail, reminiscences about Prince Charles in South Uist, and what might be a charm against evil eye [CW1/11-18]. Both Laoidh na h-Ighne, Rann Àirigh, and Rann Spréidh appear as ascribed to MacInnes in the draft contents to the work which would become Carmina Gadelica [CW124 f.2]. The title of the religious hymn Duan an Domhnaich is also under his name [CW124 fo.8].

First recorded by Carmichael a decade after he first arrived in the Outer Isles, John MacInnes was something of a late, and serendipitous, discovery for the folklorist. He had apparently eluded Hector Maclean and John Francis Campbell during their expeditions to Uist while compiling Popular Tales of the West Highlands; his name is tellingly absent from the field notes compiled by Campbell during his trip to the islands in 1871. Evidently a highly gifted seanchaidh with a wide-ranging repertoire, the example of John MacInnes suggests to us that there must have been a number of other equally capable ‘tradition bearers’ in the islands who, for whatever reason, never caught the attention of collectors. One wonders if the grandchildren who lived with John MacInnes absorbed at least some of their grandfather’s store.

In Carmina Gadelica Alexander Carmichael ascribes three items to ‘John Macinnes, Crofter, Staoligearry’. One [CG i, 82–3] is an ornate Beannachadh Leapa which exhibits occasional points of similarity with the Altachadh Leapa written down by MacRury. The two other items are a heavily polished version of MacInnes’ Rann Àirigh [CG ii, 130–1], and an extended riff by Carmichael and his assistants on Féith Mhoire, using as its starting-off point the ‘casa curra’ phrase appearing in Màiri Bhreac’s Òrtha na Buachailleachd and alluded to by MacInnes in his recording session with John Ewen MacRury in 1890 [CG ii, 132–5]. In a footnote to the list of reciters, Carmichael pays his own tribute: ‘Several volumes of old lore, mostly heroic tales, died with this nice, intelligent man’ [CG ii, 375]. John MacInnes died of ‘senile decay’ in March 1894. His grandson Angus Campbell was present.
